intro: Dicrastylis exsuccosa f. albolutea, commonly known as the white-flowered swamp lily, is a rare and striking plant native to the wetlands of southeastern Australia. It is characterized by its pale to white flowers, which contrast with its narrow, grass-like leaves. The plant typically grows in moist, swampy habitats, often in association with other aquatic or semi-aquatic flora. Its foliage is usually compact, forming dense clumps that help it thrive in waterlogged soils. Due to its limited distribution and habitat specificity, it is considered a vulnerable species in its native range.
